output.rationale: This appears to be an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models, which is a time-series approach. The abstract indicates the study reports quantitative associations and risk estimates for respiratory diseases including asthma and COPD. While the focus is on COVID-19 period comparisons, it still meets the core inclusion criteria of examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and asthma-related emergency department visits in children using a time-series design with quasi-Poisson regression. The study examines respiratory outcomes (asthma exacerbations) at ED visits, includes PM2.5 as the primary exposure of interest, and reports statistical associations. While the abstract does not explicitly report RR/OR with confidence intervals, it reports a statistically significant association (P<10-4) and provides quantitative information about the exposure-response relationship. The study design, exposure, and outcome all meet inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 exposure is analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma hospitalization which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as a specific exposure component of the AQI and stated as the primary pollutant (62% of days), (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for asthma, (4) quantitative effect estimates (ORs) with 95% CIs are reported, and (5) appears to be in English. The abstract explicitly states PM2.5-specific AQI analysis showed the strongest association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using case-crossover design; (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory discharge diagnoses); (4) Time-stratified case-crossover design; (5) Reports associations (effect estimates) with PM2.5 for respiratory outcomes. Although it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the respiratory hospitalization component is clearly analyzed and reported, making it eligible for inclusion in a review focused on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with DLNM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory disease; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049 for PM2.5); (6) published in English. Although multiple air pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department presentations AND hospitalizations for bronchiolitis; (4) study design is clearly stated as time-stratified case-crossover; (5) odds ratios with quantitative estimates are reported (>10% increased risk for PM2.5, up to 30% for NO2); (6) published in English. The study examines both ED presentations and hospitalizations for a respiratory condition (bronchiolitis).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure variable, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) time-series design, (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092,1.0405), and (6) appears to be published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is one of the main exposures analyzed with quantitative results reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) the exposure is PM2.5, (3) the outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and emergency department visits, (4) the study design is case-crossover as explicitly stated, (5) it reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) it is published in English. The study focuses on a specific vulnerable population (childhood cancer survivors) but still examines the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association in the general context.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (bronchiolitis), (4) uses a case-crossover study design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (OR: 1.04 [1.02-1.06]), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original case-crossover epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes fine particulate matter (PM2.5), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations in children, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR=1.084, 95% CI: 1.007-1.167), and (6) published in English. Although the study also examines effect modification by particle constituents and oxidative potential, PM2.5 mass concentration is a primary exposure of interest.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with effect estimates), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 infection rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome that differs from the broader category of respiratory hospitalizations (which typically include asthma, COPD, pneumonia, etc.). The review focuses on respiratory hospitalizations in general, not disease-specific infectious outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures examined; (3) The outcome is asthma emergency department visits, which qualifies as respiratory ED visits; (4) The study design is time-series (quasi-Poisson log-linear time-series models); (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported with confidence intervals (e.g., PM2.5 rate ratio of 1.016 with 95% CI: 1.008, 1.025); (6) The article is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal (Environmental Health Perspectives).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED presentations and hospital admissions, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports incidence rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals (IRR=1.043, 95% CI: 1.000-1.089 for ED; IRR=1.013, 95% CI: 0.971-1.056 for hospitalizations), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) it uses a time-series study design with generalized additive models and distributed lag nonlinear models, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates including relative risk and percentage increases in risk (e.g., 8.3% and 12.1% for temperature extremes, and positive lag effects for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants and temperature, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure, (3) respiratory disease hospitalizations are the outcome, (4) time-series design with GAM is used, (5) the results indicate that effect estimates for increased risks were reported, and (6) the article appears to be in English. The abstract indicates quantitative associations were assessed between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5 (specifically wildfire smoke PM2.5), (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, COPD, asthma, acute respiratory infections, and other respiratory diseases), (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it includes respiratory hospitalizations as specified outcomes. The medium-term (3-month) exposure window is an extension of the traditional case-crossover design but the study design still qualifies.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using generalized additive Poisson model, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations for URTI, (4) time-series design analyzing daily data, (5) reports quantitative effect estimate with 95% CI (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI 0.05-1.64%), and appears to be published in English. Upper respiratory tract infections are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for asthma and COPD. It reports quantitative risk ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 exposure (RR for asthma: 95% CI 0.981-1.148; RR for COPD: 95% CI 0.966-1.019). Although the primary findings were for NO2, PM2.5 was explicitly analyzed and reported, meeting all inclusion criteria.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, quantitative effect estimates with CI), it does not meet the study design criterion. This is explicitly described as a 'retrospective cohort study' rather than a time-series or case-crossover design. Although distributed lag models are used (which are common in time-series), the fundamental design is cohort-based with aggregated county-level hospitalization rates over person-months of follow-up, not a time-series or case-crossover analysis.

While this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure (from wildfire smoke), time-series design, and reported effect estimates with confidence intervals, the primary outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits, not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. Although respiratory outcomes were examined and mentioned as secondary findings, the study's focus and design are centered on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular outcomes, making it incompatible with the review's specific outcome criteria.

This is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (distributed lag quasi-Poisson models with daily data) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (specifically pneumonia, COPD/asthma). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (RR for pneumonia: 1.071, 95% CI: 1.025-1.118). Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it meets all inclusion criteria for respiratory outcomes.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory (pneumonia) hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, it uses a prospective cohort design rather than the required time-series or case-crossover design. The inclusion criteria specifically limit eligible studies to time-series or case-crossover designs only.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency room visits using a generalized additive model (consistent with time-series design for short-term exposure analysis). The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory ERVs. Emergency department visits meet the outcome criterion of respiratory hospitalization/ED visit.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures; (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions; (4) case-crossover design is clearly stated; (5) reports percentage change (equivalent to OR) with 95% CI for PM2.5 (1.2% increase per 10 μg/m3); (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

Although this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for RA-ILD (rheumatoid arthritis associated with interstitial lung disease), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatologic condition with respiratory complications, not general respiratory hospitalization. The review focuses on respiratory hospitalizations (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia, general respiratory diseases), not hospitalizations for autoimmune diseases that happen to have pulmonary manifestations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcome is respiratory emergency department visits (asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, upper respiratory infections); (4) study design is case-crossover (time-stratified); (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals; (6) published in English in Environmental Health Perspectives.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD, (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports excess rates (effect estimates) with 95% CIs, and (6) appears to be in English. All quantitative criteria are satisfied.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes using a time-series design (generalized additive model with lag structure), the outcome is outpatient visits rather than hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The title mentions 'hospitalization' but the abstract clearly describes the outcome as 'outpatient visits' for upper respiratory tract infections, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using Poisson regression with daily counts; (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits; (4) Study design is time-series based on daily county-level counts linked to daily PM2.5; (5) Multiple effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported (e.g., RR for respiratory disease EDV: 1.25, 95% CI: 1.21, 1.30); (6) Published in English. The study specifically reports associations between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations as well as ED visits.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for AECOPD. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (RR and RERI) with 95% CIs. AECOPD hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome. Although the study focuses on interaction effects with temperature, it includes PM2.5 as an exposure and reports effect estimates for it.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to investigate the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions in Kuwait. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5, 95% CI = 0.87, 2.35%). The exposure is PM2.5, the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, and it appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is source-specific PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for influenza and pneumonia, (4) case-crossover study design explicitly stated, (5) reports excess rates with 95% CIs (e.g., ER=9.2%, 95% CI: 4.3%, 14.3%), and (6) published in English. While the study examines source-specific PM2.5 rather than total PM2.5, PM2.5 is the primary exposure being analyzed.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive models to evaluate the association between PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (5.302% increase per 10 ug/m3, 95% CI: 3.202, 7.445). While URTI is a specific type of respiratory condition, it qualifies as a respiratory ED visit outcome. The study meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using generalized additive model; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (pneumonia and asthma); (4) time-series design indicated by the use of generalized additive model with lag dimensions and daily hospitalization rates; (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (2.22% increase per 10-unit PM2.5 increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%); (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) study design is time-series, (5) reports a quantitative effect estimate of 7.2% increase with 95% CI (1.7-13.1%), and (6) published in English. Asthma is a respiratory condition and emergency room admissions are equivalent to ED visits.

This is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for interstitial lung diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. ILD is a respiratory condition and hospitalizations for ILD qualify as respiratory hospitalizations. PM2.5 was explicitly measured and analyzed as one of multiple air pollutants.

While this is a time-series study that includes PM2.5 as an exposure and respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome with effect estimates reported, the abstract does not report the specific RR or effect estimate for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations. Only results for NO2, ozone, and noise are presented in the results section. Without confirmation that PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization associations were analyzed and reported with effect estimates, the study cannot be definitively included.

This is an original epidemiological study using time-series design (generalized additive model with distributed lag models) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (COPD admissions). The study reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increase in daily admissions). Although the abstract shows percentage changes rather than RR/OR with confidence intervals, time-series studies commonly report such estimates which can be converted to relative risks. The study meets all major inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure is investigated (along with PM2.5-10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (1.73% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The study also analyzes PM2.5-10, but PM2.5 is clearly one of the main exposures examined.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original ecological time series study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and asthma), (4) study design is time series, (5) reports relative risks with values (RR = 1.017, 1.022, 1.020 at different lags), and (6) published in English. The study uses appropriate methods (generalized additive Poisson regression) and clearly reports quantitative effect estimates.

The study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI). However, the study design is described as 'difference-in-differences approach generalized to multiple spatial units and time periods with distributed lag non-linear models,' which does not clearly fit the required time-series or case-crossover designs. While it uses daily data and appears to be ecological/time-series in nature, the difference-in-differences framework is a distinct analytical approach. This ambiguity regarding whether it constitutes a true time-series study warrants careful consideration by the review team.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures examined, (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for respiratory diseases (COPD and upper respiratory diseases), (4) it uses a case-crossover study design, (5) the abstract reports positive associations with specific lag periods indicating quantitative effect estimates were calculated, and (6) it is published in English. Although the abstract does not explicitly show RR/OR values with confidence intervals, it clearly states 'positive results were observed' with specific lag periods, indicating that quantitative effect measures were reported in the full text.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization for acute lower respiratory infections, (4) study design is explicitly stated as time-series, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (e.g., 0.73% increase; 95% CI: 0.40%, 1.06% for total ALRIs per 10-μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and (6) the abstract is in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as an exposure; (3) respiratory diseases hospitalizations are among the outcomes studied (stated as one of 7 major disease categories with robust positive associations); (4) the study uses a time-series design with quasi-Poisson regression; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (e.g., 0.21% increase with 95% CI for digestive diseases as an example, and the abstract confirms estimates were generated for all disease categories including respiratory); (6) the article appears to be in English. Although the study examines multiple disease outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly included and analyzed.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (along with PM2.5-bound PAHs) and respiratory emergency department visits for asthma. It uses a time-series design with generalized additive Poisson regression models, reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals, and asthma ERVs are a respiratory outcome meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports percentage change with 95% CI for PM2.5 (0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089%), and (6) published in English. The study also analyzes PM10 but PM2.5 is clearly one of the exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is included as an exposure, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv) which is a respiratory ED visit, (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports relative risks with specific quantitative estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although it examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is analyzed and reported with effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover design is clearly stated, (5) the results indicate associations were found and 95% confidence intervals are mentioned, suggesting effect estimates with CIs were reported, and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were studied, PM2.5 was specifically analyzed as stated in methods and results.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using GAM time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) respiratory hospitalizations are included as an outcome with a reported effect estimate (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56%), (4) the study design is time-series based on GAM methodology, (5) quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are provided, and (6) the article appears to be in English. Although the study examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, this does not exclude it from the review.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) and hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. The abstract mentions that secondary pollutants including PM2.5 were important for respiratory outcomes. The study uses Poisson regression time-series analysis and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals. While the abstract emphasizes cardiovascular results, it indicates respiratory admissions were examined and PM2.5 was associated with respiratory outcomes.

This is an original time-series study using GAMs to analyze daily hospital admissions. PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs for multiple outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations (NO2 effect on respiratory: 1.36%, 95%CI: 0.74-1.98%). Although the study examines multiple organ systems, it does include respiratory hospitalizations as one of the outcomes with reported effect estimates, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using clinical records; (2) exposure includes PM2.5; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for asthma exacerbations; (4) time-series design with Poisson regression; (5) reports RR with 95% CI; (6) published in English. All inclusion criteria are clearly satisfied.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits and PM2.5 is included as a covariate in the model, the primary exposures of interest are precipitation and temperature on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. The abstract explicitly states that PM2.5 levels were not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days. The study does not report effect estimates for PM2.5 as a primary exposure. This does not meet the inclusion criteria as PM2.5 is not the main exposure being investigated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly investigated as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute lower respiratory tract infections including pneumonia and bronchitis), (4) time-series study design with generalized additive model, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and other pollutants, and (6) published in English. The study provides specific RR values for PM2.5 (1.0064 for pneumonia at lag4 and 1.0133 for bronchitis at lag010) with confidence intervals.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), reports respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD) as outcomes, provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using Poisson regression models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) Respiratory hospital admissions are examined as an outcome; (4) Time-series design evident from 'daily counts' and city-specific Poisson regression analysis; (5) Reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals (7.5% [4.9-10.2%] for respiratory admissions per PM2.5 increase); (6) Published in English. Although UFP is the primary focus, PM2.5 results are clearly reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) study design is time-series analysis using Poisson regression, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage increase in hospitalizations per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 for different racial/ethnic groups: 8.6% for Black, 6.2% for White, 4.1% overall), and (6) published in English. The study provides clear effect estimates that can be used in a systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations, (4) uses case-crossover design with time-stratified approach, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.74% increase per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 for respiratory admissions), and (6) published in English. The study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, but respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (159,365 respiratory disease admissions); (4) uses a case-crossover design explicitly stated in methods; (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.95% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory diseases, 95% CI 1.63-2.27%); (6) published in English. The study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, but respiratory hospitalizations are clearly analyzed and reported separately.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 mass concentration itself. The study specifically focuses on the oxidative capacity of particles (OP_AA and OP_GSH) as the exposure of interest, rather than PM2.5 concentration. This does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure measure.

This is an original epidemiological study examining the association between fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. The study uses a time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models and reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Although it focuses on source apportionment of PM2.5, the exposure is still PM2.5 components, and the outcome is respiratory-related ED visits (asthma), meeting all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure; (3) Respiratory disease hospitalization is the outcome; (4) Time-series design using GAM with short-term effects analysis; (5) Quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported (e.g., 1.95% increase with 95% CI 0.25-3.67 per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5); (6) Published in English. The study examines both PM2.5 and PM10, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (specifically asthma hospitalizations are reported), (4) time-series study design, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly reports on respiratory hospitalizations including asthma, which is relevant to the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations, (4) time-series design is clearly stated, (5) reports excess risks with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (2.13%, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74%), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 results are specifically reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory healthcare visits/encounters which includes hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover analysis, (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates for PM2.5 increases, and (6) is published in English. While the outcome terminology uses 'healthcare encounters' rather than explicitly stating hospitalization/ED visits, respiratory healthcare visits for the conditions described (asthma, LRTI, URTI) in this context clearly includes emergency department visits and hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization, (4) it uses a time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) it reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5), and (6) it is published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is explicitly included with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets the key inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures investigated, (3) outcomes include ED and inpatient visits for asthma exacerbation which are respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits, (4) rate ratios with confidence intervals are reported. While the abstract primarily presents results for grass pollen and the study focuses on effect modification by viral infections, PM2.5 associations are part of the analysis. The outcome of asthma exacerbation visits meets the respiratory hospitalization/ED visit criterion.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models (GAM), which is appropriate for time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of multiple air pollutant exposures examined; (3) the outcome includes hospital admissions for patients with respiratory diseases (comorbid with diabetes); (4) the use of GAM with daily data indicates a time-series design; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (7.25% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5); (6) the article appears to be in English. While the population is restricted to those with diabetes mellitus comorbidity, the outcome is still respiratory hospitalization, which fits the review criteria.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95%CI), the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which typically include common colds, pharyngitis, and similar conditions. These are generally distinct from the lower respiratory conditions (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia) that are the focus of respiratory hospitalization reviews. AURTIs represent upper airway infections rather than the more severe lower respiratory conditions typically requiring hospitalization.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive models; (2) PM2.5 is examined as a primary exposure; (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for asthma, which is a respiratory condition; (4) the study design is explicitly stated as time-series; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (e.g., 6.1% increase, 95% CI: 2.1-10.3%); (6) the article appears to be in English. Although the outcome is specifically asthma rather than all respiratory conditions, asthma ED visits are a valid respiratory hospitalization/ED outcome for this type of review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study, not a review or commentary; (2) Exposure is PM2.5 (fine particulate matter <2.5 μm); (3) Outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations; (4) Study design is case time series analysis, which is a variant of time-series design; (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.43% increase per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5, 95% CI: 1.34%, 1.52% for respiratory hospitalizations); (6) Published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the respiratory hospitalization component is clearly reported and meets all criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD admissions), (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports effect estimate with 95% CI (1.6%, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English

While this study meets several criteria (case-crossover design, reports OR with CI, includes PM2.5 as one exposure, published in English), the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' rather than specifically hospitalization or ED visit. The abstract mentions 'hospital visits' in the objectives but the actual measured outcome appears to be asthma exacerbations/visits requiring prednisone treatment, which is not clearly defined as hospitalization or ED visit. Additionally, the primary exposure focus is ultrafine particles, not PM2.5, and the results section explicitly states 'We observed no such associations with...fine particles (≤2.5μm)', indicating no significant PM2.5 effect.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports associations/effect estimates for PM2.5 with respiratory admissions in both single and multi-pollutant models, and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD hospitalizations), (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR 1.26, 95% CI: 1.06-1.50), and (6) published in English. The study examines the association between PM2.5 exposure and COPD hospitalizations using a time-stratified case-crossover design with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure, (3) includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, (4) uses a case-crossover design as indicated in the title and confirmed by use of conditional logistic regression, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.26% increase, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31% for respiratory admissions per 10 μg/m³ increase in PM2.5), and (6) is published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using Quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model, which is consistent with time-series methodology; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions (asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis); (4) the study design is time-series based on the methods description (daily hospital admissions data with control for temporal trends, seasonality, weather); (5) relative risks with 95% confidence intervals are reported for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations; (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 results are specifically reported for respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia) as the outcome, provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals, and appears to be published in English.

The primary exposure studied is coarse particles (PM 2.5-10 µm), not PM2.5. While the abstract mentions PM2.5 in the introduction and as a covariate adjustment, the main exposure of interest is coarse particles. This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 as the exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with GAM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization specifically for asthma; (4) it uses a time-series study design; (5) it reports relative risk estimates with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 for PM2.5); and (6) the article appears to be published in English. Asthma hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization that is relevant to the systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome includes both respiratory ED visits and hospitalizations for COPD exacerbation, (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports relative risks with specific values for PM2.5, and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure, (3) respiratory emergency department visits are the outcome, (4) time-series design was used, (5) rate ratios with 95% credible intervals are reported for PM2.5 and respiratory ED visits, and (6) it is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design; exposure is source-specific PM2.5; outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits; quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (e.g., excess risk for respiratory EDVs and asthma); and it appears to be published in English.

This is an original time-series study that examines PM2.5 (among other pollutants) as an exposure and asthma hospitalizations (a respiratory outcome) as the outcome. The methods describe generalized additive models for time-series analysis, and the results indicate that quantitative effect estimates were calculated (positive and significant impacts, attributable risks). Asthma hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome. Although the abstract doesn't explicitly state confidence intervals, the mention of 'significant impacts' and 'attributable risks' strongly suggests quantitative effect measures with uncertainty estimates were reported in the full text.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design with DLNM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) Outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) Study design is time-series regression; (5) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5); (6) Published in English. While the study examines multiple air pollutants, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) Outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) Time-series study design using generalized additive model; (5) Reports effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5 increase, 95% CI 0.21-2.26%); (6) Published in English. The study examines multiple pollutants but PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures, examines respiratory emergency department visits (asthma ED visits), reports rate ratios (RRs) as effect estimates, and appears to be published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included.

Although the study examines PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as one exposure and respiratory hospitalizations as the outcome using a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson regression), the abstract only reports quantitative effect estimates for temperature (18% increase in risk for 4°C temperature increase), not for PM2.5. The study appears to focus primarily on temperature effects, and no PM2.5-specific effect estimate with confidence interval is provided in the abstract. Without a reported effect estimate for PM2.5, it does not meet inclusion criterion #5.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (and ozone) exposure in relation to cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (risk ratios) with values provided for respiratory disease outcomes. While the primary focus is comparing different visit types, it meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, includes PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits as outcomes, uses time-series design, and reports risk ratios for respiratory outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study with a case time series design (variant of time-series); (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits; (4) Study design is case time series, which is a time-series approach; (5) Reports excess relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 1.34% for respiratory ED visits); (6) Published in English. The study examines multiple outcomes including respiratory disease, which is relevant to the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is COPD exacerbation hospitalizations which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs (1.030 [1.006-1.055] for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbations requiring hospitalization clearly fall under respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (both total and source-specific) and respiratory hospitalizations among other outcomes. The study explicitly mentions respiratory hospital admissions as an outcome, uses a time-series design with generalized linear models, and reports associations (effect estimates) between PM2.5 and hospitalizations. It meets all major inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models with distributed lag models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for pediatric asthma, which is a respiratory ED visit; (4) the study design is time-series (daily ED visits analyzed with GAM); (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported as relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.011, 95% CI: 1.002, 1.021 for PM2.5); and (6) the article is published in English. Although multiple pollutants were studied, PM2.5 was specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as an exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma admissions), (4) study design is case-crossover (title) with time-series analysis, (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (RR=1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 per 10 µg/m3), and (6) published in English. Although the title mentions case-crossover and the abstract mentions time-series, both are acceptable study designs for inclusion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (ALRI, pneumonia, bronchiolitis) in children. The study reports quantitative effect estimates as relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075-1.103 for PM2.5). The abstract is in English and the study design is explicitly described as time-series regression analysis.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (including asthma-related hospitalizations). The study uses Poisson regression with a time-series approach (examining associations across lag days 0-6, adjusted for temporal factors). The study reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations. All inclusion criteria are met.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency room admissions in children. Although the results showed no significant association between PM2.5 and ER admissions, the study explicitly measured PM2.5 exposure, reported quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, used appropriate time-series methodology (Poisson regression), and focused on respiratory ED visits. The fact that PM2.5 showed null findings does not exclude it from a systematic review, as null results are important for comprehensive evidence synthesis.

While this study uses PM2.5 as an exposure measure and includes respiratory hospitalizations as one outcome, it is an interrupted time series study examining LONG-TERM effects (8 years post-fire) rather than the short-term time-series or case-crossover design required. The study design (interrupted time series evaluating a single discrete event) differs fundamentally from the standard time-series designs that examine day-to-day or short-term variations in PM2.5 and health outcomes. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly indicate whether quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported specifically for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using an 18-year time-series design, (2) PM2.5 (including speciated organic carbon fraction) is among the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory ED visits for infections including bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, and URI, (4) it uses a time-series study design with Poisson generalized linear models, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 4% increase with 95% CI: 2%, 6% for URI; 8% increase with 95% CI: 4%, 13% for pneumonia), and (6) it is published in English. Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 components were specifically included and analyzed.

This study examines pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis hospitalizations, which are cardiovascular/hematological outcomes, not respiratory hospitalizations. Additionally, the exposure measured was PM10, not PM2.5. The study does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome type or exposure specification.

The outcome is suicide death, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Although the exposure involves particulate matter and uses a time-series design with effect estimates, the health outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a review article (as stated in the title 'A critical review'), not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5), and the outcome is mortality (not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit).

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis of other studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure includes PM10 but does not specifically mention PM2.5.

This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) of cardiac origin, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The study specifically focuses on cardiac outcomes, which does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an animal study (mice) investigating the biological mechanism of PM2.5-induced lung injury and protective effects of Astragaloside IV. It is not an epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations in humans. The study design is an experimental animal model, not time-series or case-crossover. The outcome is lung injury biomarkers, not hospitalization or ED visits.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('this review is focused on these aspects') that discusses historical, physicochemical, and pathological aspects of particulate matter and lung diseases. It is not an original epidemiological study and does not report specific effect estimates for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm), as the exposure of interest. While the outcome (respiratory hospitalizations for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) meet inclusion criteria, the exposure does not match the systematic review's requirement for PM2.5 specifically.

While this study includes a multisite time-series analysis component with PM2.5 exposure and appears to report effect estimates, the outcome is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The abstract specifically states 'statistically significant associations between short-term changes in elemental carbon and cardiovascular hospital admissions.' This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory outcomes.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as the exposure. While the study is an original time-series analysis that reports effect estimates with confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations, it does not meet the fundamental inclusion criterion of PM2.5 exposure. The study focuses specifically on PM10 from desert and non-desert sources.

The study examines PM10, not PM2.5. While it meets other inclusion criteria (case-crossover design, respiratory hospitalizations as outcome, quantitative effect estimates reported), the exposure is specifically PM10 (particles ≤10 μm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm) as required by the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95%CI), the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm). The inclusion criteria specifically require PM2.5 or fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm, and PM10 includes both fine and coarse particles and is not equivalent to PM2.5.

This appears to be a health impact assessment/policy evaluation study rather than an original epidemiological study. The abstract states that 'a literature review was carried out to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and 'public health gains were calculated based on the selected relative risks', indicating that the authors used existing effect estimates from the literature rather than conducting an original time-series or case-crossover analysis. The study calculates avoidable hospitalizations based on compliance with air quality standards using borrowed relative risks, which does not meet the criterion for an original epidemiological study with its own effect estimates.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the primary outcome analyzed is ambulance dispatches, which is a pre-hospital emergency response indicator rather than actual hospitalization or ED visit data.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the outcome inclusion criteria.

This study examines cardiovascular events (CVE), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. Both the outcome and exposure do not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines cardiovascular mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The outcome does not meet inclusion criteria, which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Additionally, the study examines PM10 (particulate matter below 10 μm) rather than PM2.5.

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The text explicitly states 'This systematic review was conducted' and mentions including '196 articles in quantitative analysis'. The outcome is also mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a review/book chapter that summarizes existing literature rather than an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

The study examines mortality from myocardial infarction (MI), which is a cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Although the study includes PM2.5 exposure and uses a case-crossover design with effect estimates, it does not meet the outcome inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that examines PM2.5 exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 (coarse particulate matter) exposure from mineral dust, not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). The outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While the study design is case-crossover which meets criteria, both the exposure type and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study using interrupted time-series analysis to examine respiratory hospital visits with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The abstract explicitly states 'Particulate matter of 10 microns in diameter or smaller (PM10) concentrations' were measured. The study evaluates the effect of a burning ban intervention rather than directly examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations, which is the focus of the systematic review.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5) exposure and ischemic stroke hospitalizations, not PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. Both the exposure type (coarse PM, not PM2.5) and outcome (cardiovascular/stroke, not respiratory) do not meet the inclusion criteria.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design, quantitative effect estimates with CIs), it examines mortality as the outcome rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on cause-specific daily mortality including respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospital admissions or ED visits.

This is a systematic literature review, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the review discusses studies that examined PM2.5 and respiratory infections, the paper itself is a synthesis of existing literature rather than presenting original data or effect estimates.
This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits). Both the exposure type and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.

Study examines PM10 (particulate matter <10µm) rather than PM2.5 (particulate matter <2.5µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is years of life lost (YLL) from respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While it is a time-series study with quantitative effect estimates, it does not meet the key inclusion criteria for exposure (PM2.5) or outcome (hospitalization/ED visit).

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and the exclusion criteria explicitly exclude meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcomes are primarily mortality (respiratory mortality, cardiovascular mortality, etc.) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

The study examines PM10 and NO2 exposures, not PM2.5. While it includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome and uses appropriate study designs (Poisson regression/time-series for hospitalizations and case-crossover for mortality) with quantitative effect estimates, it does not meet the PM2.5 exposure inclusion criterion. PM2.5 is not mentioned anywhere in the abstract.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter <10 μm) and ozone as exposures, not PM2.5 (particulate matter ≤2.5 μm). Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and the outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for the systematic review.

This study does not meet inclusion criteria. The exposure is PM10, NO2, and SO2, but NOT PM2.5. The outcome is respiratory disease mortality and lung cancer mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. While it is a time-series study with effect estimates, the absence of PM2.5 as an exposure and mortality (rather than hospitalization) as an outcome disqualify it from this systematic review.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5, as the primary exposure. The outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Although it is a time-series study with effect estimates, it fails to meet the inclusion criteria for both exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

Study fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) Exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, (2) Outcome is mortality (cause-specific deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While the study uses appropriate time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the exposure and outcome do not match the review criteria.

This study examines respiratory mortality (deaths) as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original time-series epidemiological study with effect estimates, it fails to meet critical inclusion criteria: (1) the exposure is ultrafine and fine particle number/surface area concentrations and PM10, NOT PM2.5, and (2) the outcome is mortality, NOT respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The study examines daily cause-specific mortality including respiratory mortality, but mortality is not the outcome of interest for this systematic review.

The study examines mortality outcomes, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, NO2, and O3, but not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and coronary heart disease hospitalization (not respiratory hospitalization). It fails to meet the inclusion criteria for both exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Although it uses a time-series design with PM2.5 exposure, the primary outcome is economic losses due to mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as the outcome.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10, not PM2.5) as the primary exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure using a case-crossover design with effect estimates and confidence intervals, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory/thoracic cancer) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The study does not report on hospital admissions or emergency department visits for respiratory conditions.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. It fails both inclusion criteria #1 (must be original study, not review) and #3 (outcome must be respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on years of life lost and mortality counts rather than hospital admissions.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause and specific-cause including respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The study does not meet inclusion criterion 3, which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or ED visit as the outcome.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause mortality in elderly), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Although the study meets other criteria (PM2.5 exposure, time-series and case-crossover designs, quantitative effect estimates), it does not meet the outcome inclusion criterion.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The abstract explicitly states 'We conducted a rapid systematic review and meta-analysis following PRISMA guidelines' and describes screening 163 articles and extracting data from 14 eligible studies. Reviews and meta-analyses are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CIs), the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or ED visits. The study examines respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The study specifically examines 'daily deaths' and 'respiratory mortality', not hospital admissions or emergency department visits for respiratory conditions.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the underlying studies may have examined PM2.5 exposure and respiratory morbidity, this publication itself is a synthesis of other studies.

The outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The study examines mortality (nonaccidental, cardiovascular, and respiratory) as the health outcome, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization/ED visits.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure using a time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The inclusion criteria specifically require respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as the outcome.

This appears to be a summary report of an integrated research program (NPACT Initiative) that includes multiple types of studies (time-series epidemiology, animal studies, and in-vitro studies) rather than a single original epidemiological study. The outcomes mentioned are 'morbidity and mortality' without specific mention of respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Additionally, while it mentions a time-series component (Ito study), this publication appears to be an overview/report of the entire initiative rather than an original study reporting specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a meta-analysis/pooled analysis comparing statistical methods rather than an original epidemiological study. The outcome is respiratory mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria. While PM2.5 is included as an exposure and time-series design is used, the study fails on two critical inclusion criteria: it is not an original study (it is a meta-analysis of existing data) and the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization/ED visits.

The study examines ozone exposure (not PM2.5 as primary exposure) and mortality outcomes (not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits). While the study design is time-series and includes effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the exposure or outcome criteria for inclusion.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study examines deaths (natural, cardiac, cerebrovascular, and respiratory mortality) rather than hospital admissions or ED visits, which is the required outcome for this systematic review.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining heart failure outcomes (not respiratory hospitalizations). It fails to meet inclusion criteria 1 (original study) and 3 (respiratory outcome).

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('have been described in this review'), not an original epidemiological study. It discusses general health effects of PM2.5 including mechanisms and pathways, but does not present original data with quantitative effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence'), not an original epidemiological study. It does not report primary data or original effect estimates. Reviews are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcomes focus on neurologic health and disease (stroke, migraine, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria #1 (not original research) and #3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title explicitly states 'systematic review and meta-analysis' and the abstract describes pooling effect estimates from 145 identified studies. This violates inclusion criterion 1 and meets the first exclusion criterion.

This is a review article focusing on biological mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death, not an original epidemiological study. It does not examine respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, does not use time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report quantitative effect estimates like RR or OR.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction (MI), which is a cardiovascular outcome, not a respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not an original study) and 3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. The title clearly states it is a 'Systematic review and meta-analysis' and the methods describe searching databases and combining risk estimates from 59 studies.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, while the study examines PM2.5 constituents and includes respiratory morbidity as one outcome, it primarily focuses on mortality outcomes and is synthesizing data from other studies rather than presenting original data.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. It fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring original research and meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review article was prepared based on peer-reviewed scientific papers'), not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is chronic kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. It fails both the study type criterion (exclusion: reviews) and outcome criterion (inclusion: respiratory hospitalization/ED visit required).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes evidence from multiple studies rather than presenting primary data. Additionally, the outcome reported is respiratory and cardiovascular mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses.
This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we discussed...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality (death) as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Additionally, the study design is a cohort study with long-term exposure assessment, not a time-series or case-crossover design as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial discussing the general health effects of wildfires and PM2.5. It does not report original epidemiological research, lacks a specific study design (time-series or case-crossover), does not report quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, or CI), and does not describe specific respiratory hospitalization or ED visit outcomes from an original analysis.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we summarize...') and focuses on vascular endothelial cell toxicity rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It does not meet inclusion criteria 1 (not an original epidemiological study) or 3 (outcome is not respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This is a rapid review/systematic review that synthesizes evidence from other studies rather than an original epidemiological study. It explicitly states it used 'Cochrane rapid review methodology' and reviewed 450 manuscripts. Reviews are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit as specified in the inclusion criteria.

This is explicitly identified as a review article in the title ('A review of implications for human health'), not an original epidemiological study. It does not report original data collection or quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals. It discusses the general health impacts of PM2.5 and ammonia but does not present original research on PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a review article (explicitly states 'This review summarizes and discusses studies') focusing on neurological outcomes (Alzheimer's disease and dementia), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails multiple inclusion criteria: not an original epidemiological study, wrong outcome.

This study fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study, and (2) the outcome is myocardial infarction (cardiovascular hospitalization), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Although PM2.5 exposure is examined, the outcome does not match the review focus on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between air pollution and ocular surface disease (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria.

This is explicitly a review article ('In this review, we primarily focus on...') focusing on cardiovascular outcomes (VSMCs, vascular diseases) and mechanistic pathways rather than respiratory hospitalizations. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for being an original epidemiological study with respiratory hospitalization outcomes.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes rather than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. Additionally, the narrative style and concluding recommendations suggest this is a review or commentary article rather than an original epidemiological study with quantitative effect estimates.
